<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module2_mcq_q60')" data-correct-answer="C">
<strong style="display: block;">
An investor allocates 70% of wealth to stocks and 30% to bonds.  
- Expected return of stocks: 14%, volatility = 20%  
- Expected return of bonds: 6%, volatility = 8%  
- Correlation between stock and bond returns: 0.2  

What is the portfolio’s standard deviation (σp)?
</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q60" value="A"> A. 11.0%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q60" value="B"> B. 11.5%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q60" value="C"> C. 14.8%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q60" value="D"> D. 15.5%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q60" value="E"> E. 16.0%</label><br>
</form>
<div id="feedback-module2_mcq_q60" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: C.  
The portfolio variance is:  
σp² = (0.7²)(0.20²) + (0.3²)(0.08²) + 2(0.7)(0.3)(0.20)(0.08)(0.2).  

= 0.0196 + 0.000576 + 0.004704 = 0.02488.  

Thus, σp = √0.02488 ≈ **14.8%**.  

This demonstrates that portfolio risk depends on **weights, volatilities, and correlations**, not just expected returns.
</div>
